A preview of the initial performance of the Johns Ho~kins
Playshop, Margaret Fleming, by
James Herne, a drama of the
nineties, revealed an admirably
executed, well interpreted and altogether most enjoyable production. The first performance wiil
be given Wednesday night, November 17, and every night thereafter until Saturday.
Probably the most striking
feature of the play is that it is
so typical of the period which it
represents, ~hat there is no sense
of anachronism, no strangeness.
The audience is completely and
almost immediately transported
back some fifty years, and remains there with slight relapses
at the numerous intermissions.
Perhaps the costuming is in part
responsible for the splendid illusion, but one is inclined to think
that the quality of the character
interpretations, are re sponsible in
no small degree for its success.

Since the beginning of the semester, a new personality has graced
our campus, obsequous, courteous,
and differential, performing his
duty with the least possible noise
and annoyance. We refer to Special
Officer number 650, assigned to the
Hopkins beat, and better known in
College circles as the Campus Cop.
The word personality was used
advisedly. Officer 650 is a personality, but his inherent modesty and
shyness have prevented any flaunting of his virtues. In fact the
hardest part of an interview with
him was to keep him from expounding eulogies on the ability of Hopkins men to get in and 0!1t of jams
(traffic) and get him to talk about
himself. After being repeatedly
assured that being mentioned in the
NEWS-LETTER would not ruin an
otherwise unsullied reputation, the
following bit of biography was revealed.

Of

Mr. Robert Andrew Mueller, or
"Bob" for short. The Mueller, he
assures us, no matter how you pronounce it, is Irish, and it goes without saying that the shamrock is
Bob's favorite flower. He is married, has two children, and has been
a resident of the fair city of Baltimore all his life. His favorite
pastime is playing auto - license
poker with himself, and it is thus
that he whiles away the time while
on duty. He never bets on this
game, since he is continually beating himself, but it has been whispered that perhaps the fact that the
University pays his salary has
something to do with it.
This is Bob's first venture in the
Civil Police, but in the three years
and a month he spent in France,
he was a member of the Military
Police for six months, but did not
care to mention how long he had
worked with the K. P. He prefers
Out of uniform, officer 650 is

but after the Terrors got going

was the stronger team. Every
thing the Westminster player
tried worked successfully.

Instead of devoting most o
their attack to lineplunging, the
Terrors took to the aerial route
and beat the Jays at their own
game.
Time after time long

lent passes on the part o
Doughty or Jones.
Jay Defense Poor
With all credit to Western
Maryland, this weak defensive
work on the part of Hopkin
may not only be attributed to
the Terrors' supreme power
Hopkins, previous to this game

of a defensive game.

novel experience. At least it

Terrors continued to reel off one

the ball on Hopkins' 48-yard line
Bolton and Doughty carried i
to the Jays' 4-yard line.
Jones pulled a fast one and
threw, to his left, a forward to

Jones' kick was blocked and the

In a fiew moments the big
Green team followed up with

after the ball had slipped: like an
eel out of the hands of to Jay
players. In earning this touch
down Western Marylan~ gave a
good exhibition of deceptive play

EDITORIALS
MRS. AMES
It is fair to say that the death
of Mrs. Ames is an event which
touches the life of every member of
The Johns Hopkins University.
And this is true in spite of the fact
that her prolonged ill health had
made impossible any immediate relations with most of the present
members. Yet such was the unique
quality of her personality, and such
is the particular loss to Dr. Ames,
that the life of all is in a true if
not immediate sense so touched.
Those who had in the past been
so fortunate as to enjoy a closer
intimacy with Mrs. Ames. can declare how unique that personality
was, for it combined keen wit,
downright honesty, dauutless courage, and unfailing kindness, all of
these with a fineness of breeding
and an individual charm which was
entirely her own. Such a blending
of qualities, as rare as beneficent
and delightful, must leave a lasting
impression not measured by immediate contacts alone.
Doubtless it is a fault of an educational community like our own
that we do not possess better facilities for the expression of sympathy:
but at least Dr. Ames must know
that every member of the University is aware of what he has suffered, and is grateful for the way
he has borne this suffering, and still
continued to labor for our common
good. Dr. Ames must know that
at this hour all of us sorrov\' with
him in his loss.

THE BELLS-Not Poe's
It has been brought to our attention recently that some of the bells
in the University are not ringing
at the beginning ancl ending of certain periods.
As a result of this, the professors
become so involved in this work,
that they completely forget to think
about the end of the period, and
invariably run over the time. This
is especi;lly hard on th~se who have
1 r.3o's in rooms where the bells du
not ring. The students are kept
anywhere from five to fifteen minutes over-time and as a result are
invariably late for meetings or
luncheon engagements.
\Ye suggest that this matter be
looked into immediately and the
bells that are at fault repaired.

Hopkins Professor Leads Discussion on Beard's Books on
American Constitution
Charles A. Beard, the historian,
was the subject of a talk by Dr.
Frederick C. Lane, Associate in
History, before the Liberal Club
last Friday.
Constitution, Economic Biography
According to Dr. Lane, Dr.
Beard belongs to the pre-war generation of liberals. His well known
book, The Economic Interpretation
of the Constitution may well be regarded as an "economic biography"
of the men who wrote the docurnent, showing that they are directly interested in and derived economic advantage from the estabiishment of the Constitution. This
view of the "apostolic fathers of
America was a shock to the rotariaris."
Government Undemocratic
• Beard brings out that the government was never intended to be
an unlimited democracy, but a
careful system of checks and balances aimed to protect property.
Beard's expose of the formation of
the constitution was partly responsible for the modern spirit of cynicism that prevails in so many circles
today. Dr. Lane expressly stressed,
however, that Beard himself is an
idealist.
Dr. Beard was characterized as a
man of great and high ideals, a
deep and scientific thinker, and a
sympathiser with "the underdog ...

convention is in the hands of Mr.
Fay Campbell, of Buffalo, chairman of the program committee,
and is divided into three parts,
coming under the three heads of
Humanity Uprooted, effective Missions Today, and The Future of
World Christianity.

Dr. Ernest Ooos, visiting professor. in the geology department, presents one of the most diversified
personalities on the Hopkins faculty. Invited here from Germany
where he does research work for
the University at Bonn, the doctor
will remain . on the campus until
May, as a resident lecturer in structural geology.
Praises Faculty-Student Relations
He had great praise for the
spirit of serious purpose that pervades work at the Hopkins. The
spirit of familiarity that exists between professors and students is
especially appealing to him. Baltimore hospitality was characterized
as "practically unlimited."
ls Native German
The doctor was born May 17,
1898, at Saarbruecken, Germany.
He attended high school and one
year of university in the city of
Freiburg. The next three years
were divided between Universities
of Breslau and Gottingen. He
took his doctor of philosophy de-

gree from the former, and remained for a year as assistant in
geology under Professor . Stille.
From there he went to Hanover.
His personal life is one of a lover
of travel and strange lands. It
was this inclination to travel and
be out of doors that led to his
choosing geology as his life work.
Has Traveled Much
His travels have taken him all
through Europe from Italy to the
Scandanavian Peninsula, and into
Asia as far as Mesopotamia. He
spent two years in Texas and Louisiana. Feillowing this he returned
to Germany, later making anotli.er
visit to this country-this time to
California. These trips were made
for purposes of research, the doctor not being specifically connected
with any university at the time.
Although he keeps an apartment

Is World War Hero
A member of an aviation unit
during the World War, Doctor
Cloos has a distinguished record.
Although he is very reticent concerning any honors, it was learned
that he was twice the recipient of
the Iron Cross. His plane was shot
down three times, in the last instance his opponent _being, he believes, an American. He managed
to bring his bullet-riddled machine
to earth, but Jost his observer.
In addition to his work at the
Hopkins, the doctor is doing some
individual work in the country outside of Baltimore.

Playshop, Margaret Fleming, by
James Herne, a drama of the
nineties, revealed an admirably
executed, well interpreted and altogether most enjoyable production. The first performance wiil
be given Wednesday night, November 17, and every night thereafter until Saturday.
Probably the most striking
feature of the play is that it is
so typical of the period which it
represents, ~hat there is no sense
of anachronism, no strangeness.
The audience is completely and
almost immediately transported
back some fifty years, and remains there with slight relapses
at the numerous intermissions.
Perhaps the costuming is in part
responsible for the splendid illusion, but one is inclined to think
that the quality of the character
interpretations, are re sponsible in
no small degree for its success.

EDITORIALS
MRS. AMES
It is fair to say that the death
of Mrs. Ames is an event which
touches the life of every member of
The Johns Hopkins University.
And this is true in spite of the fact
that her prolonged ill health had
made impossible any immediate relations with most of the present
members. Yet such was the unique
quality of her personality, and such
is the particular loss to Dr. Ames,
that the life of all is in a true if
not immediate sense so touched.
Those who had in the past been
so fortunate as to enjoy a closer
intimacy with Mrs. Ames. can declare how unique that personality
was, for it combined keen wit,
downright honesty, dauutless courage, and unfailing kindness, all of
these with a fineness of breeding
and an individual charm which was
entirely her own. Such a blending
of qualities, as rare as beneficent
and delightful, must leave a lasting
impression not measured by immediate contacts alone.
Doubtless it is a fault of an educational community like our own
that we do not possess better facilities for the expression of sympathy:
but at least Dr. Ames must know
that every member of the University is aware of what he has suffered, and is grateful for the way
he has borne this suffering, and still
continued to labor for our common
good. Dr. Ames must know that
at this hour all of us sorrov\' with
him in his loss.

bells that are at fault repaired.

Sir:
The idea that University classes
should begin at 8.30, instead of at

that they could render.

itself into how to have the provision for earlier classes passed.

Hopkins Professor Leads Discussion on Beard's Books on
American Constitution
Charles A. Beard, the historian,
was the subject of a talk by Dr.
Frederick C. Lane, Associate in
History, before the Liberal Club
last Friday.
Constitution, Economic Biography
According to Dr. Lane, Dr.
Beard belongs to the pre-war generation of liberals. His well known
book, The Economic Interpretation
of the Constitution may well be regarded as an "economic biography"
of the men who wrote the docurnent, showing that they are directly interested in and derived economic advantage from the estabiishment of the Constitution. This
view of the "apostolic fathers of
America was a shock to the rotariaris."
Government Undemocratic
• Beard brings out that the government was never intended to be
an unlimited democracy, but a
careful system of checks and balances aimed to protect property.
Beard's expose of the formation of
the constitution was partly responsible for the modern spirit of cynicism that prevails in so many circles
today. Dr. Lane expressly stressed,
however, that Beard himself is an
idealist.
Dr. Beard was characterized as a
man of great and high ideals, a
deep and scientific thinker, and a
sympathiser with "the underdog ...

NOW BEING CHOSEN
Hopkins To Send Men .To Convention Of Students At
Buffalo
A delegation which is to represent the Hopkins at the eleventh
quadrennial convention of the
Student Volunteer Movement, to
be held t.his year at Buffalo, N.
Y., from December 30, 1931-January 3, 1932, is now being selected, is was announced.
Starting in 1887, these conventions have been held every four
years, with the result that thousands of men and women are now
in active missionary work abroad.
Discussion In Three Sections
The program of this year's
convention is in the hands of Mr.
Fay Campbell, of Buffalo, chairman of the program committee,
and is divided into three parts,
coming under the three heads of
Humanity Uprooted, effective Missions Today, and The Future of
World Christianity.

Serious Purpose of Students;
Is War Hero
Dr. Ernest Ooos, visiting professor. in the geology department, presents one of the most diversified
personalities on the Hopkins faculty. Invited here from Germany
where he does research work for
the University at Bonn, the doctor
will remain . on the campus until
May, as a resident lecturer in structural geology.
Praises Faculty-Student Relations
He had great praise for the
spirit of serious purpose that pervades work at the Hopkins. The
spirit of familiarity that exists between professors and students is
especially appealing to him. Baltimore hospitality was characterized
as "practically unlimited."
ls Native German
The doctor was born May 17,
1898, at Saarbruecken, Germany.
He attended high school and one
year of university in the city of
Freiburg. The next three years
were divided between Universities
of Breslau and Gottingen. He
took his doctor of philosophy de-

gree from the former, and remained for a year as assistant in
geology under Professor . Stille.
From there he went to Hanover.
His personal life is one of a lover
of travel and strange lands. It
was this inclination to travel and
be out of doors that led to his
choosing geology as his life work.
Has Traveled Much
His travels have taken him all
through Europe from Italy to the
Scandanavian Peninsula, and into
Asia as far as Mesopotamia. He
spent two years in Texas and Louisiana. Feillowing this he returned
to Germany, later making anotli.er
visit to this country-this time to
California. These trips were made
for purposes of research, the doctor not being specifically connected
with any university at the time.
Although he keeps an apartment

Is World War Hero
A member of an aviation unit
during the World War, Doctor
Cloos has a distinguished record.
Although he is very reticent concerning any honors, it was learned
that he was twice the recipient of
the Iron Cross. His plane was shot
down three times, in the last instance his opponent _being, he believes, an American. He managed
to bring his bullet-riddled machine
to earth, but Jost his observer.
In addition to his work at the
Hopkins, the doctor is doing some
individual work in the country outside of Baltimore.
